Definition.Document:
Run Length Optimization

 

Background: 

Many manufacturing units hit process throughput constraints over the course of a run. These constraints are often reversible, but at the cost of shutting down to clean/maintain equipment. Sometimes the decision to shutdown and clean equipment, regaining throughput rate upon start-up, enables a unit to meet their production goals sooner. Meeting targets sooner translates into more production (& $$) over time. 

Scenario: 

A manufacturing production unit needs to produce 50,000 klb of the product that they are running. The supply chain for this product is tight and the customer needs the full order filled ASAP. 

The production rate for this product decreases at a relatively constant linear rate due to equipment fouling and plugging constraints. A 12-hour shutdown (production rate = 0 klb/h) can be taken at any point during a product run in order to recover production rate. 

Data: 

  • Production Rate

Date Range: 

  • Jan 1, 2020 12:00 AM - Mar 1, 2020 12:00 AM

Strategy:

To minimize the time taken to produce a given order quantity, you must maximize production rate over the long-term. You can assume that every production time period also has an associated downtime, but that the final (1) downtime does not impact order delivery date as it comes after the full order is produced.


Reset

Base Case Analysis Steps:

1) Create a capsule for this run - extend the capsule into the future far enough that it will capture the end of the run even with degrading production rates. (step)

2) Calculate the total time elapsed since the beginning of the production run. (step)

3) Create a predictive model of the production rate based on the time signal. (step)

4) Create a combined signal of the Production Rate data that exists and the prediction for the future training. (step)

5) Integrate the projected signal to create a production totalizer. (step)

6) Identify when 50,000 klb is produced. (step)

  • Order ready to ship on March 12, 2020 at 4:25 PM


Alternative Analysis Steps:

1) Create a capsule spanning the time over which production rate data exists for this run. (step)

2) Calculate the total time elapsed since the beginning of the production run. (step)

3) Calculate a totalizer signal for a given amount of product produced at any point during the run. (step)

4) Calculate the number of downtimes that would be required to fulfill the order quantity at any point in the production cycle. (step)

5) Calculate the Average Production Rate at each point during the current run time. (step)

6) Calculate the total run time (including downtimes) required to produce the given order quantity based on the number of required downtimes. (step)

7) Find the Minimum run time required using Signal from Condition. (step)

8) Create a new condition showing the full order fulfillment time. View the date that the order will be ready to ship in the capsules pane. (step)

  • Based on 4 downtimes and 5 run times to produce the desired amount, downtimes should be taken every 284.88 h of run time [(1472.4 h total time - 48 h of downtime) / 5 run times].
  • The order will be ready to ship on March 2, 2020 at 1:24 AM Pacific

9) Identify the production rate at the point of min runtime. This can be used as a trigger for taking a proactive downtime. (step)

10) Build a Reference Profile for the ideal production cycles to monitor current operations against. (step)


Promotional - Run Length Optimization - Demo (May 18, 2021 9:53 AM)


Conclusion:

By periodically shutting down to ensure all equipment is operating as best possible, the production unit was able to fulfill the order 10.5 days sooner (an 11% improvement on their typical fulfillment time). In a high demand environment, this operational change has the ability to increase sales volumes and revenues by an equal percentage. 

Visual Comparison

By periodically shutting down to ensure all equipment is operating as best possible, the production unit was able to fulfill the order 10.5 days sooner (an 11% improvement on their typical fulfillment time). In a high demand environment, this operational change has the ability to increase sales volumes and revenues by an equal percentage. 

Production Rate with Future Projection

Production Target met

Run Length Optimization

 

Background: 

Many manufacturing units hit process throughput constraints over the course of a run. These constraints are often reversible, but at the cost of shutting down to clean/maintain equipment. Sometimes the decision to shutdown and clean equipment, regaining throughput rate upon start-up, enables a unit to meet their production goals sooner. Meeting targets sooner translates into more production (& $$) over time. 

Scenario: 

A manufacturing production unit needs to produce 50,000 klb of the product that they are running. The supply chain for this product is tight and the customer needs the full order filled ASAP. 

The production rate for this product decreases at a relatively constant linear rate due to equipment fouling and plugging constraints. A 12-hour shutdown (production rate = 0 klb/h) can be taken at any point during a product run in order to recover production rate. 

Data: 

  • Production Rate

Date Range: 

  • Jan 1, 2020 12:00 AM - Mar 1, 2020 12:00 AM

Strategy:

To minimize the time taken to produce a given order quantity, you must maximize production rate over the long-term. You can assume that every production time period also has an associated downtime, but that the final (1) downtime does not impact order delivery date as it comes after the full order is produced.


Base Case Analysis Steps:

1) Create a capsule for this run - extend the capsule into the future far enough that it will capture the end of the run. (step)

2) Calculate the total time elapsed since the beginning of the production run. (step)

3) Create a predictive model of the production rate based on the time signal. (step)

4) Create a combined signal of the Production Rate data that exists and the prediction for the future training. (step)

5) Integrate the projected signal to create a production totalizer. (step)

6) Identify when 50,000 klb is produced. (step)

  • Order ready to ship on March 12, 2020 at 4:25 PM


Alternative Analysis Steps:

1) Create a capsule spanning the time over which production rate data exists for this run. (step)

2) Calculate the total time elapsed since the beginning of the production run. (step)

3) Calculate a totalizer signal for a given amount of product produced at any point during the run. (step)

4) Calculate the number of downtimes that would be required to fulfill the order quantity at any point in the production cycle. (step)

5) Calculate the Average Production Rate at each point during the current run time. (step)

6) Calculate the total run time (including downtimes) required to produce the given order quantity based on the number of required downtimes. (step)

7) Find the Minimum run time required using Signal from Condition. (step)

8) Create a new condition showing the full order fulfillment time. View the date that the order will be ready to ship in the capsules pane. (step)

  • Based on 4 downtimes and 5 run times to produce the desired amount, downtimes should be taken every 284.88 h of run time [(1472.4 h total time - 48 h of downtime) / 5 run times].
  • The order will be ready to ship on March 2, 2020 at 3:24 AM

9) Identify the production rate at the point of min runtime. This can be used as a trigger for taking a proactive downtime. (step)

10) Build a Reference Profile for the ideal production cycles to monitor current operations against. (step)


Conclusion:

Vis

By periodically shutting down to ensure all equipment is operating as best possible, the production unit was able to fulfill the order 10.5 days sooner (an 11% improvement on their typical fulfillment time). In a high demand environment, this operational change has the ability to increase sales volumes and revenues by an equal percentage.
